metadata.title: When will we see the first wave of AI IPOs? | by Bastiane Huang | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: When will we see the first wave of AI IPOs?
metadata.description: We’ve seen 7 AI companies exited valued at $1B+. Is this the first arriving signal of a giant IPO wave? Why are there few AI IPOs in the United States? Is the US falling behind in the race for AI domi

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: a shift from mobile-first to AI (Artificial Intelligence)-first strategy
AI is going to have a bigger impact on the world than some of the most ubiquitous innovations in history like fire or electricity
7 AI companies exited via IPO or M&A valued at $1B+
record high funding into US AI startups,
US AI startups are expected to break funding records in 2019.
40% of European AI startups don’t actually use AI.

She writes about ML, robotics, and product management. Follow her here

all_paragraphs: On July 10, 2008, Apple launched the App Store with an initial of only 500 applications available. Shortly afterwards, Google announced its mobile-first strategy in 2010. Since then, we’ve seen a wave of massive mobile app IPOs: Evernote in 2012, Twitter in 2013, King (the company behind Candy Crush) in 2014, Tinder in 2015, Snapchat and Line in 2016.

Fast forward to 2017, Google CEO Sundar Pichai announced a shift from mobile-first to AI (Artificial Intelligence)-first strategy. He later added that AI is going to have a bigger impact on the world than some of the most ubiquitous innovations in history like fire or electricity. Two years later, today, we’ve seen “7 AI companies exited via IPO or M&A valued at $1B+ — four of which have taken place in the last 2 years.” Is this the first arriving signal of a giant IPO wave?

Interestingly, despite a record high funding into US AI startups, we see fewer US companies the IPO pipeline. The two AI IPOs valued over $1B: NIO is a Chinese electric autonomous vehicle maker. And Mobileye is an Israeli company that makes cameras and software to help cars avoid accidents. If you google “AI IPO,” you will see news like “Chinese AI startup Megvii plans for an IPO.” and “South Korea’s JLK Inspection is going public.” but no mention of US startups on the first page.
Why are there fewer AI IPOs in the United States? Is it just a matter of time? Or is the US falling behind in the race for AI dominance?
The U.S. leads in the AI startup scene but not IPO. Why?

The answer is “Absolutely not.” In fact, the US is leading the AI startup scene: 77 out of the top 100 AI startups are from the States. In comparison, there are only 8 Chinese companies on the list. In addition, according to the National Venture Capital Association, 965 AI-related companies in the U.S. have raised $13.5 billion in the first 9 months of this year. US AI startups are expected to break funding records in 2019. So why aren’t there more startups filing for IPOs?

The number of AI startup acquisitions doubled in 2016 and increased by an average of 46% in the following years. And US tech giants are dominating AI startup acquisitions: Apple (acquired 20 startups so far), Google (14), Microsoft (10), Facebook (8), Intel (8), and Amazon (7) are the most aggressive acquirers of AI startups, according to CB Insights. On the other hand, the vast majority of acquirers (431) have only acquired a single AI company.

But more interesting is when you look at the changes in the market value of these tech giants: a significant increase in value over the past few years, especially since 2017, when you started to see a jump in AI acquisitions. This explains why we’ve seen more AI IPOs in places other than the U.S. AI startups here are more likely to get acquired before IPO.

In 2013, Apple, Microsoft, Google, and Intel were already among the top 10 most valuable companies in the world. But they weren’t so far apart from S&P 500 (^GSPC, the grey line above) until the last few years. The tech giants have widened their gap over the past few years.
What does that mean to startups and other companies?

In the past, every time there is technology innovation, we see major industry reshuffles. Small companies disrupt incumbents and introduced phones, personal computers, digital photographs, and streaming videos.

Tech incumbents like Google, Facebook, Apple, and Amazon, are more prepared than anyone else. They have advantages in data, capital, and talents to not only outcompete innovative startups but also disrupt traditional industry players. Among all, retail & CPG has the highest number of AI acquisitions (67 in total since 2010), followed by media & entertainment, healthcare, finance & insurance, and transportation & logistics.

So far Google, Apple, and Microsoft have each acquired 10+ AI startups. And recently traditional incumbents slowly started to react: Roche acquired Flatiron Health. Nike acquired AI-powered inventory management startup Celect. And McDonald’s acquired personalization platform Dynamic Yield.

What makes it even trickier for traditional industry players is that AI is invisible. With previous technological innovations like the internet and mobile app, we can easily tell good/innovative products from the bad ones. But it’s not always easy to do so with AI products. For example, you don’t really know if the security robot patrolling your building is fully autonomous powered by AI or remotely controlled by a human.

Despite all the hype, the truth is that there haven’t been that many AI products on the market yet. Over 80% of the companies are looking into AI but most of them still try to identify use cases that would create actual value. We only started to see AI-enabled robots deployed in the field very recently. And venture capital firm MMC claimed that 40% of European AI startups don’t actually use AI. It’s hard for outsiders to know what’s actually going on.

AI will no doubt have a huge impact across industries but “AI as a Product” is still in its infancy. It’s probably too early to predicate the first wave of AI IPOs. But it’s clear that traditional incumbents are facing more challenges than ever this time, not only from nimble startups but also from AI-powered tech giants. If you are working for a traditional company and trying to adopt AI, focus on where you can leverage your domain expertise and create practical value. “AI is the new electricity. It will transform every industry and create huge economic value,” said Andrew Ng. But you don’t have to be an electricity company to exploit the value. You just need to know how to apply the technology to your advantage.

Bastiane Huang is a Product Manager at OSARO, a San Francisco based startup building software-defined robotics. She has worked for Amazon in its Alexa group and with Harvard Business Review as well as the university’s Future of Work Initiative. She writes about ML, robotics, and product management. Follow her here.
